metadata.synopsis: Jaheira's default dialogue. Topics range from her past life to her current goals as they develop. Unless otherwise stated, her tone is confident and to the point. She's a seasoned adventurer with a sardonic sense of humour - and a little less cynical than she might present herself to be.

223.speaker: Jaheira
223.text: We faced Bhaal there once before, and I was not ready to count on luck a second time. But luck had no part in it - just you.

214.speaker: Minsc
214.text: Well. You, and a certain miniature giant space hamster. But mostly you, true.

268.speaker: Jaheira
268.text: That is both Chosen beaten, and their stones wrested from their grasp. But where they fall, the elder brain rises.

293.speaker: Jaheira
293.text: It is already worming its way free. We must find it before it slips its collar, whether we are ready or not.

118.speaker: Jaheira
118.text: And now it is Gortash's turn. We'll need his stone to finish this - however you plan to acquire it. So let us go pay Lord Liar a visit.

12.speaker: Jaheira
12.text: Minsc certainly made his home in that hideout - but he's up to something somewhere else.
12.context: InternalNodeContext: I'll definitely need to revisit this for a flag later - For now if you use the debug book to teleport to the Abandoned Cistern interior and haven't done the robbery scene, it should be accessible

16.speaker: Jaheira
16.text: Congratulations are in order. I fancied myself the sage advisor, sworn to guide you through what it means to be a child of Bhaal.

89.speaker: Jaheira
89.text: And while I mulled on that solemn responsibility - you went and took care of it on your own.

180.speaker: Minsc
180.text: Well done indeed! Though now you will never see a god of death cower before a miniature giant space hamster. Every choice has a cost, I suppose.

235.speaker: Jaheira
235.text: The path of a Bhaalspawn is not an easy one - nor does it ever truly end.

279.speaker: Jaheira
279.text: But you found your footing where so many before you have fallen. Wherever you lead from now, we will follow.

181.speaker: Jaheira
181.text: But you found your footing where so many before you have fallen. Wherever you lead from now, we will follow.

108.speaker: Jaheira
108.text: I wonder if Gortash knows just who it is he is dealing with.

9.speaker: Jaheira
9.text: I believe you have an appointment with a Netherbrain.

19.speaker: Jaheira
19.text: Are you... well? You have a rather vacant, tadpole-finally-ate-my-brain look about you.

151.speaker: Player
151.text: I think Minsc might have fled down into the sewers.

239.speaker: Jaheira
239.text: The Undercity is perilous, but I recall Minsc making a home down there in the old days. 'To plant his boot on the very bosom of evil', or some such.

261.speaker: Jaheira
261.text: I'll mark an entrance I know - from there, we shall just have to follow our noses.

81.speaker: Jaheira
81.text: Of course. You're no true Baldurian unless you've sloshed around in the slurry, after all.

43.speaker: Jaheira
43.text: Now now - I need a moment.

291.speaker: Player
291.text: Tell her about what happened at the Counting House.

127.speaker: Jaheira
127.text: Stlarning shapechangers. And of course the fool would follow their every word, just because they wear my face.

236.speaker: Jaheira
236.text: Well - first things first, I owe you an apology. I did not tell you of all I hoped to find in the city.

144.speaker: Player
144.text: Tell her about the encounter with Nine-Fingers.

21.speaker: Jaheira
21.text: Ah. The guildmaster wishes to see us, does she? Better we call on her home than she call on ours. Lead, then.

116.speaker: Jaheira
116.text: Ah. I know what she speaks of. I need... information from her. And a pardon from you - for I have not been overly generous with the truth.

173.speaker: Player
173.text: Care to discuss that scroll of yours?

250.speaker: Player
250.text: I found a strange scroll in your sanctuary. Something about a 'timeless body'?

58.speaker: Player
58.text: Have you thought any more about how we might find Minsc?

168.speaker: Jaheira
168.text: I have. And while I do not love my conclusion, that does nothing to change it.
168.context: NodeContext: Grudgingly coming to a conclusion

77.speaker: Jaheira
77.text: The Harpers are the city's best information network. With them out of action, we shall have to fall back on second-best.
77.context: NodeContext: Jaheira's Harpers have been infiltrated, she can't use them.

11.speaker: Narrator
11.text: *Nine-Fingers. As a child, your father spoke her name in anxious whispers. She runs the Guild - which in turn runs every criminal enterprise in the city.*

270.speaker: Wyll
270.text: Nine-Fingers - a name that could make a city guard tremble. If they aren't already on her payroll, that is.

52.speaker: Wyll
52.text: She runs the Guild. Which itself runs every criminal enterprise in the city.

88.speaker: Narrator
88.text: *A name known, and feared, throughout the city's underworld. The mysterious Keene runs the Guild - which in turn runs every criminal enterprise in the city.*

205.speaker: Player
205.text: The Guild? You'd throw your lot in with thieves?

186.speaker: Jaheira
186.text: Nine-Fingers is much more than a thief. Nothing happens in this city that she doesn't learn of, sooner or later.

85.speaker: Player
85.text: I didn't think a Harper would be friends with a petty crime lord.

67.speaker: Jaheira
67.text: 'Friend' is not the word I'd use. Nor is 'petty', if you've a mind to keep your tongue.
67.context: NodeContext: Warning us not to dismiss Nine-Fingers

161.speaker: Jaheira
161.text: But both our operations step outside the law when needful. She just likes it better there.

15.speaker: Player
15.text: She is no one to be trifled with.

256.speaker: Jaheira
256.text: Nor are we. But I trust she knows the value of collaboration, especially in times like these.
256.context: NodeContext: Rationalising her willingess to deal with a crime lord.

128.speaker: Player
128.text: You say that like it should mean something.

201.speaker: Jaheira
201.text: If it does not, you have led a very virtuous life indeed.
201.context: NodeContext: Surprised we haven't heard of a big crime boss she named - Nine-Fingers

47.speaker: Jaheira
47.text: Nine-Fingers Keene controls the Guild, which in turn controls every criminal racket from Heapside to the High Hall.

6.speaker: Jaheira
6.text: Nothing happens in this city that she doesn't hear of, sooner or later.

69.speaker: Jaheira
69.text: How hospitable she will be to a Harper that comes begging to her Guildhall... we will find out. Perhaps I will let you do the talking.
69.context: NodeContext: Not relishing the idea of walking into an enemy's lair.

209.speaker: Jaheira
209.context: NodeContext: Surprised we haven't heard of a big crime boss she named - Nine-Fingers

64.speaker: Player
64.text: You mentioned there might be another way to find Minsc.

124.speaker: Jaheira
124.text: There might be, but... it is not a path I'd tread until we must.

92.speaker: Jaheira
92.text: Let it wait until the city proper. Perhaps I'll have had a better idea by then.

109.speaker: Player
109.text: Jaheira, ma'am, I can't tell you what it means to me to be working together.

24.speaker: Player
24.text: Jaheira, ma'am, I can't tell you what it means to me to be working together.

86.speaker: Jaheira
86.text: I ought to be saying that to you, girl. Only one of us here clawed her way free of the Hells themselves.

78.speaker: Jaheira
78.text: But if you insist on calling me ma'am, I'll happily snap a few orders while you do all the work?
78.context: NodeContext: wryly, she's kidding here but playing it tough

104.speaker: Player
104.text: Is it true you once out-spelled an eladrin druid in her own grove?

50.speaker: Jaheira
50.text: Ah. I know that one. They say I turned the very blades of grass against her. Her staff of office leapt into my hand, naming me its rightful wielder.

191.speaker: Jaheira
191.text: Close. When I realised she was far the better mage, I snatched it from her and used it for a club. I fear I do not live up to campfire tales.

230.speaker: Player
230.text: Fine with me. As far as I'm concerned, you say 'jump' and I say 'how high'.

126.speaker: Jaheira
126.text: Pfft. Do not feign smallness, girl - it doesn't suit you. I am the follower here. Though I would ask we keep the jumping to a minimum.

0.speaker: Player
0.text: You don't understand. You've been an idol of mine for years.

105.speaker: Jaheira
105.text: Leave idols to the druids - we already tie ourselves in knots over them. Let me be your follower instead. Your friend, even.

190.speaker: Jaheira
190.text: But if you need proof that I am flesh and blood, Karlach, and none the fresher for it - perhaps we might train together at camp.

63.speaker: Jaheira
63.text: Look alive, girl! Recall our arrangement - I give the orders, you do all the work.

7.speaker: Player
7.text: Thank you, Jaheira. That would be fantastic.

18.speaker: Jaheira
18.text: See if you still feel the same afterwards.
18.context: NodeContext: being tough but with warmth underneath it.

185.speaker: Player
185.text: I'd be too terrified of accidentally hurting the Jaheira.

171.speaker: Jaheira
171.text: Oh, so kind. And so naive.
171.context: NodeContext: being tough but with warmth underneath it.

38.speaker: Player
38.text: Discuss what happened at the Harper safe-house.

57.speaker: Player
57.text: Tell her what happened at the Harper safe-house.

276.speaker: Player
276.text: How are you faring without your Harpers?

277.speaker: Player
277.text: I met your family. Rion is rather keen to see you.

103.speaker: Player
103.text: Why didn't you tell me about your family?

264.speaker: Player
264.text: Now we're travelling together, I realise I don't know much about you.

94.speaker: Jaheira
94.text: You know enough. And so do I.
94.context: NodeContext: She dislikes the player - tone is making it clear we work together, but not to expect more than that.

282.speaker: Jaheira
282.text: That speaks well of your taste. I've heard my share of bad ballads about things I never did.
282.context: NodeContext: Happy that we don't know much about her. Not a big fan of her fame - she has work to do.

212.speaker: Player
212.text: I wanted to ask you something.

125.speaker: Player
125.text: You have a history with Sarevok.

176.speaker: Jaheira
176.text: Nothing so grand. He was just another broken little Bhaalspawn, who tried to clamber to glory over the corpses of others.

288.speaker: Jaheira
288.text: There was a time when he might have made more of himself - he was certainly given the chance, after we threw him down.

245.speaker: Jaheira
245.text: But he slunk back into his father's shadow instead. Let him be a cautionary tale to you - your father will only love you so long as he can use you.

183.speaker: Jaheira
183.text: But he slunk back into his father's shadow instead. There is nothing more to say of him.

136.speaker: Jaheira
136.text: As do you, now. And all our hands are stained by association. I can see the greater good in it, should it lead us to Orin.

149.speaker: Jaheira
149.text: To which we've added a low and craven chapter. I can see the greater good in it, should it lead us to Orin.

147.speaker: Player
147.text: We need to part ways for the moment. I'll find you at camp.

274.speaker: Jaheira
274.text: Now is not the best moment to leave. You'll just have to put up with me, for now.

164.speaker: Jaheira
164.text: We are a little ways from our camp here. You'll just have to put up with me, for now.

42.speaker: Player
42.text: We need to part ways for the moment. I'll see you back here.

192.speaker: Jaheira
192.text: Back and forth. You're like to make me dizzy.
192.context: NodeContext: wry "these young folk are so changeable"

143.speaker: Jaheira
143.text: Later, then. I'd tell you not to get in trouble, but I suspect it will find you whether you like it or not.
143.context: NodeContext: Not offended - tweaking our noses a bit, but tone is mild

248.speaker: Jaheira
248.text: You have enough fine young folk to run around and do your bidding. Come back when they need a rest.

66.speaker: Jaheira
66.text: I asked for your help. Set us on course for what happened at the Guildhall. So perhaps I have no right to question.

45.speaker: Jaheira
45.text: But whatever your feelings on Nine-Fingers - whatever mine - I cannot see how we served the city by putting the Zhentarim in her place.

142.speaker: Player
142.text: I'm sorry, Jaheira. I know she was your friend - but the city is better off without her.

229.speaker: Jaheira
229.text: I have no illusions about who Astele was. She was a criminal. A brute, even, when she had to be.

213.speaker: Player
213.text: Simple. The Zhentarim follow gold - not the whims of any guildmaster.

207.speaker: Jaheira
207.text: Astele did not have whims. She was a criminal, yes. Even a brute, when she had to be.

199.speaker: Jaheira
199.text: But her every act, even those I opposed, was done in service to her city. No matter her personal feelings.

258.speaker: Player
258.text: We didn't. The city's free of the Zhentarim - and now the guildmaster's whims, too.

159.speaker: Player
159.text: Are you forgetting that she wanted Minsc dead?

87.speaker: Jaheira
87.text: That instinct is what allowed our alliance to endure so long as it did - that she could place her personal feelings aside, and do what she thought best for the city.

158.speaker: Jaheira
158.text: So it seems I must honour that, and do the same. But mark my words: when the Absolute is finished, when all of this is done - the city will feel her loss.

178.speaker: Player
178.text: You're right. You have no right to question.

272.speaker: Jaheira
272.text: ...As you say, then. My friend is saved, and we have another ally in the fight against the Absolute.

244.speaker: Jaheira
244.text: I shall be content with that. For now.

97.speaker: Jaheira
97.context: NodeContext: Flat, disinterested - this is a greeting specifically if we've pissed her off for any reason, and she's not inclined to chitchat.

141.speaker: Jaheira
141.text: A true pleasure, to watch you tell the Archduke exactly where to put his alliance.

91.speaker: Jaheira
91.text: One cannot embrace a viper - only get entangled by it.

146.speaker: Jaheira
146.text: Amble about if you wish. I plan to claim whatever little rest remains.

34.speaker: Jaheira
34.text: Huh. Not so much a term of age or affection as simple old habit. You object?

76.speaker: Jaheira
76.text: As you like. No cub, no fun.

123.speaker: Player
123.text: Not so long as I get to call you crow.

138.speaker: Jaheira
138.text: 'The Cub and the Crow' - sounds like a cautionary tale. As it probably should.

59.speaker: Jaheira
59.text: And will be again. But now I shall mutter them under my breath, out of respect.

154.speaker: Jaheira
154.text: Watching gods, but I never thought I would be happy to see this city again. Much less to smell it.
154.context: NodeContext: Looking around at the city in which's spent most of her life - unintentionally. She's a druid, and would rather be out in the wilds - but this is still her home.

281.speaker: Jaheira
281.text: The Harper safe-house I spoke of is on the bridge at Wyrm's Crossing - Danthelon's Dancing Axe.

61.speaker: Player
61.text: What are you hoping to find there, again?

56.speaker: Jaheira
56.text: Information. The Chosen have a head start on us - I'd like to know what they've done with it.

170.speaker: Jaheira
170.text: I would be lying if I told you I was certain we would walk out of that temple alive.

193.speaker: Jaheira
193.text: There's little point in pressing Nine-Fingers further. She means what she says.

228.speaker: Jaheira
228.text: But we swore no vows. She won't tell us where to find Minsc, someone else in her Guildhall will. We need to be swift.

169.speaker: Player
169.text: Where do you suggest we begin?

249.speaker: Jaheira
249.text: I suppose we must greet the local wild-life. The Guildhall is awash with ale-scented gossip at the best of times.

72.speaker: Jaheira
72.text: These days, they have nothing but the Stone Lord to talk about.

20.speaker: Player
20.text: There's something else I wanted to discuss.

195.speaker: Jaheira
195.text: A fine thing, to travel in a small pack once more. No doubt Ketheric thinks he has escaped us.

204.speaker: Jaheira
204.text: Speak, so long as you have something sensible to say.

232.speaker: Jaheira
232.text: The great Archduke's coronation became his funeral rite. At least the flowers will not go to waste.

29.speaker: Jaheira
29.text: Perhaps it is uncouth to have taken pleasure in that. I am content to be uncouth.

267.speaker: Jaheira
267.text: And we learned something. One Chosen thinks to send us against the other, while they sit safe behind their defences.

65.speaker: Jaheira
65.text: Good. Ketheric thought he was safe, too.

234.speaker: Jaheira
234.text: I need to think a while.

242.speaker: Jaheira
242.text: One final night in the open air, and then back to the city. Rest while you can - I fear that quite a bit of work awaits us.

257.speaker: Jaheira
257.text: I would not linger in this land overlong. But - whatever your business, I will aid you if I can.

265.speaker: Jaheira
265.text: Well - are we ready for the road once more?
265.context: NodeContext: Neutral to positive, general slice-of-life greetings in camp.

266.speaker: Jaheira
266.text: I've had a lifetime's fill of watching little men puff themselves up with grand titles.

101.speaker: Jaheira
101.text: I look forward to the day we show the Archduke that his tongue is not half so silvered as he thinks.

216.speaker: Jaheira
216.text: He's protected by his Steel Watch for now - and Orin will have her own defences, should we choose to play the part of Gortash's bloodhounds.

131.speaker: Player
131.text: As do I - but we agreed to deal with Orin first.

273.speaker: Jaheira
273.text: We need all three stones to command the brain. It matters little in what order we obtain them, or how.

150.speaker: Player
150.text: He seems more cooperative than Orin, at least.

133.speaker: Jaheira
133.text: Of course. He'll share his rule - what use all his brilliance, if there is no one to bask in it?

233.speaker: Jaheira
233.text: But even if we unite to command the brain, it's not as if we can leave the city under Bane's boot-heel once it's done. We'd be back to the same old battle.

112.speaker: Player
112.text: You're not interested in his offer?

211.speaker: Jaheira
211.text: To work together? Strangely enough, I believe him - he's too self-important to be anything but sincere.

145.speaker: Player
145.text: We can't pick a fight while he's surrounded by his Steel Watch.

46.speaker: Jaheira
46.text: We could. It would just be a very short one.

84.speaker: Jaheira
84.text: We cannot expect either of the Chosen to fall easily. But fall they must, if we're to have all three stones to command the brain.

79.speaker: Jaheira
79.text: Still, if you see sense in making an alliance, I won't question it. I'll just look forward to the inevitable breaking Gortash spoke of.

100.speaker: Player
100.text: And what do you think of his warning - of the doppelganger in our camp?

167.speaker: Jaheira
167.text: It would be irritatingly true to form, would it not?

120.speaker: Jaheira
120.text: A Harper learns to doubt. To peer through every smile, question every look. Eventually you find whatever it is you fear, whether it is there or not.

3.speaker: Jaheira
3.text: When we cannot know, we can only trust. But then, that is exactly what a traitor in our midst would say - isn't it?

292.speaker: Jaheira
292.text: Fools. As if the promise of any amount of gold would make them Dame Aylin's equal.
